author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Ursula von der Leyen Seeks Second Term as Top E.U. Official
description: The German politician has been European Commission president since 2019, becoming a key contact for the Biden administration.
content: “Who do I call if I want to call Europe?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Dozens Killed After Gunfight in Papua New Guinea
description: The bloodshed in Enga Province, which has been plagued by violence between tribal groups, left at least 26 people dead, according to the authorities.
content: More than two dozen people were killed in a gunfight on Sunday in the remote highlands of Papua New Guinea, where deadly violence between more than a dozen tribal groups has been escalating. The precise cause of the latest episode remained unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Navalny’s Widow Pledges to Carry On Opposition Leader’s Work
description: The sudden death of Aleksei Navalny left a vacuum in Russia’s opposition. His wife, Yulia Navalnaya, signaled that she would try to fill the void.
content: The widow of Aleksei A. Navalny said on Monday that she would carry on her husband’s work to challenge President Vladimir V. Putin’s autocratic rule, presenting herself for the first time as a political force and calling on his followers to rally alongside her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: We Can Still Resist a Pipeline to Hell
description: As the planet hurtles toward an irreversible climate tipping point, natural gas projects will further devastate the environment.
content: Earlier this month, the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Company announced its intention to build the South’s largest gas pipeline in more than a decade. The Southeast Supply Enhancement project, as the company calls it, would run from Virginia down through the Carolinas and Georgia before swinging west to Alabama, right through the heart of the American South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Let Tesla Expand? Three German Teens Have a Few Thoughts.
description: The U.S. automaker’s plan to enlarge its operations outside Berlin has divided local residents. Some worry about the environmental costs; others see job prospects.
content: Tesla’s hulking assembly plant outside Berlin, which opened two years ago in a community known for its forests and lakes, still rubs many residents the wrong way. They worry it threatens the quality of their water and air, and has disrupted the peacefulness that drew them to the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Vivek Shankar and Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Overwhelmed by War, Another Gazan Hospital Is Declared ‘Not Functional’
description: Conditions at Nasser Hospital in the southern Gaza Strip were described as desperate after Israeli forces raided it in search of Hamas militants.
content: The largest medical facility still managing to function in wartime Gaza is now a hospital in little more than name only, the head of the World Health Organization said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Shaken by Grisly Killings of Women, Activists in Africa Demand Change
description: The continent has the highest rate of gender-related killings of women in the world, according to the United Nations. Activists accuse officials of ignoring the issue and blaming the victims.
content: A wave of gruesome killings of women across several African countries in recent weeks has prompted outrage and indignation, triggered a wave of protests and precipitated calls for governments to take decisive action against gender-based violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Russia Cracks Down on Navalny Mourners, and Trump’s $400 Sneakers
description: Plus, U.N. Court Considers Israel
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Where the New Ye Meets the Old Kanye
description: “Vultures 1,” the rapper’s album with Ty Dolla Sign, arrived on the 20th anniversary of his debut, “The College Dropout.”
content: The old Kanye, the new Kanye. Kanye then, Kanye now. Few, if any, popular musicians have made as much hay from the tension between their prior selves and their current one. And no famous person perpetually sheds old fans and acquires new ones quite like Kanye West, now known as Ye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: After Fleeing Ukraine, a Tattoo Artist Settles Into Life in Brooklyn
description: Once the war started, Alona Hamova worked as a guest artist at tattoo studios in Europe, and when she thought she was ready, accepted an offer to work in Williamsburg.
content: It was war that drove Alona Hamova from her home, but, in a way, she always knew she was destined to leave. “I felt like I didn’t fit there,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: Teachers Are Missing More School, and There Are Too Few Substitutes
description: In some districts, teachers are taking more sick days since the pandemic. A shortage of substitutes can make matters worse.
content: Schools across the country have faced no shortage of challenges since the pandemic. Students are behind academically. Cases of misbehavior are up. Students are absent far more frequently than before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: The ‘Sad, Happy Life’ of Carson McCullers
description: A new biography chronicles this essential American writer’s complicated love life, celebrated career and singular talents.
content: Mary V. Dearborn’s new book, “Carson McCullers: A Life,” is the first major biography of this essential American writer in more than 20 years. It is competent and professional, as if built from solid pine and good plaster. It is dispassionate and well researched. Reading it is brutal because McCullers’s life was brutal to endure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: If You Liked ‘Saltburn,’ Consider This Much Better Movie
description: “The Dreamers,” Bernardo Bertolucci’s notorious 2004 coming-of-age drama, pushes the same buttons, but it makes serious points along the way.
content: I was at my mom’s house in the suburbs when I watched Barry Keoghan make love to his bestie’s grave in Emerald Fennell’s “Saltburn.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Barnard
title: Quietly Dressing Hollywood’s Cool Girls
description: Stars like Ayo Edebiri, Greta Lee and Olivia Rodrigo trust Danielle Goldberg when they need to look their best.
content: Danielle Goldberg was sitting at a table with her eyes glued to a laptop screen. On it was the actress Greta Lee, who was trying on a satin gown the same color as the flesh of a banana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Everyone Knows Sutton Foster Can Sing. Now We Know She Can Juggle.
description: How the Broadway star simultaneously mastered leading roles in “Once Upon a Mattress” and “Sweeney Todd.”
content: There’s busy, and then there’s bonkers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Inside Aleksei Navalny’s Final Months, in His Own Words
description: Trump. Indian food. Matthew Perry. And books, books, books. Excerpts from letters obtained by The Times show Mr. Navalny’s active mind, even amid brutal prison conditions.
content: Confined to cold, concrete cells and often alone with his books, Aleksei A. Navalny sought solace in letters. To one acquaintance, he wrote in July that no one could understand Russian prison life “without having been here,” adding in his deadpan humor: “But there’s no need to be here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deirdre Mask
title: How to Speak New York
description: In “Language City,” the linguist Ross Perlin chronicles some of the precious traditions hanging on in the world’s most linguistically diverse metropolis.
content: “Up on the sixth floor of an old commercial building along the sunless canyon of 18th Street, there is a room where languages from all over the world converge.” It makes sense that the Endangered Language Alliance, the only organization in the world focused on “the linguistic diversity of cities,” lives here, in a donated office in the most linguistically diverse metropolis on earth. It is also here that Ross Perlin begins “Language City,” his gorgeous new narrative of New York, as told through the hundreds of languages spoken in its five boroughs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: U.S. Strike Killed Afghans Recruited to Fight for Iran
description: Refugees who joined the largely overlooked Fatemiyoun Brigade to battle for Shiite Islam and escape crushing poverty had become a force in Tehran’s proxy wars.
content: It was a memorial for the “martyrs” killed when the U.S. struck military bases in Syria, according to Iranian state television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark and Ana Swanson
title: Plans to Expand U.S. Chip Manufacturing Are Running Into Obstacles
description: Delays in finishing new factories are emerging, just as the Biden administration begins handing out money to stoke domestic production.
content: In December 2022, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the key maker of the world’s most cutting-edge chips, said it planned to spend $40 billion in Arizona on its first major U.S. hub for semiconductor production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: The Weirdest, Wildest Performances of the Year
description: Wesley Morris gives out awards for acting categories that don’t exist at the Oscars.
content: They call the annual parade of prizes for art “award season.” It lasts for months and reliably culminates in somebody standing on a stage saying “thank you” (or sometimes “no thank you”). Meanwhile, we at home might understand that we’re looking at a winner, but almost never do we know why they’ve won. Lots of hardware, no citation. So, since its inception, The New York Times Magazine’s Great Performers issue has tried to be enlightening about what makes certain good acting stand out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova and Paulo Motoryn
title: Brazil’s President Lula Recalls Ambassador to Israel, Escalating Dispute
description: The Israeli foreign minister said Mr. Lula was not welcome in the country until he took back remarks comparing Israeli actions in the war against Hamas to the Holocaust.
content: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil recalled his ambassador to Israel on Monday, as tensions escalated between the countries over the Brazilian leader’s sharp remarks against Israel’s war on Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruhullah Khapalwak
title: U.N. Held a Conference on Afghanistan. Taliban Officials Boycotted It.
description: The group said it would not take part in a conference that also included women’s rights groups, the European Union and representatives of Afghan civil society.
content: DOHA, Qatar — Taliban officials sent a defiant message to Western nations, donors and Afghan women’s groups this week, refusing to attend a conference hosted by the United Nations to discuss humanitarian crises facing Afghanistan and cooperation on human rights issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: What Is a Species, Anyway?
description: Some of the best known species on Earth may not be what they seem.
content: Naturalists have been trying for centuries to catalog all of the species on Earth, and the effort remains one of the great unfinished jobs in science. So far, researchers have named about 2.3 million species, but there are millions — perhaps even billions — left to be discovered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The New York Times Wins 3 Polk Awards
description: The Times was honored for its coverage of the Israel-Hamas war. And ProPublica won a prize for revealing the lavish gifts and luxury trips given to Justice Clarence Thomas.
content: The New York Times on Monday won three George Polk awards, including two for its coverage of the Israel-Hamas war. The prizes were among the five that honored journalism on that conflict and the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Your First Step Toward a Better Mood
description: Poor sleep can make anxiety, depression and other mental health issues worse. Here’s what to do about it.
content: It started with mild anxiety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adelle Waldman
title: It’s Not Just Wages. Retailers Are Mistreating Workers in a More Insidious Way.
description: Part-time work has become a trap.
content: Back in 2018, with an eye to writing a novel about low-wage work in America, I got a job at a big-box store near the Catskills in New York, where I live. I was on the team that unloaded the truck of new merchandise each day at 4 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Republican Attacks on Biden’s Climate Law Raise Concerns Ahead of Election
description: Executives of companies with clean energy projects are facing questions about the potential for a rollback of the law and its incentives if a Republican wins.
content: The United States has experienced a surge in clean energy projects, representing more than $200 billion in new investments since President Biden signed an expansive climate bill into law more than a year ago. But the election and the potential for a Republican takeover is prompting concern that key parts of the law could be upended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: More Wall Street Firms Are Flip-Flopping on Climate. Here’s Why.
description: Financial giants were already trimming their climate pledges amid Republican attacks. Then came concerns about legal risks.
content: Many of the world’s biggest financial firms spent the past several years burnishing their environmental images by pledging to use their financial muscle to fight climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ari L. Goldman
title: Rabbi Jules Harlow, 92, Dies; Helped Redefine Conservative Jewish Prayer
description: Rabbi Harlow’s prayer books, including “Siddur Sim Shalom,” became the standards of worship in Conservative synagogues across North America.
content: Rabbi Jules Harlow, a liturgist who brought a poet’s sensibility and a musician’s cadence to the style of prayer in Conservative Judaism for much of the second half of the 20th century, died on Feb. 12. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh, Vik Jolly and Orlando Mayorquin
title: Latest Atmospheric River Brings Heavy Rain, Flooding and Thunderstorms to California
description: Monday’s storm did not appear to be as damaging as the one earlier this month, but more rain is expected over the next few days.
content: Much of California was pounded by another wave of rain on Monday in the latest storm to test the state after a deadly deluge caused widespread power outages and destructive mudslides two weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Simple Yet Surprising Skillet Ginger Chicken With Apricots
description: This weeknight one-dish meal packs a lot of punch, with savory cumin and coriander, sweet dried apricots and fresh mint.
content: Cold February nights call for slowly simmered stews and braises; heady, savory aromas; and bowls of succulent, fall-off-the-bone meats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Misty White Sidell
title: What’s So Special About a Rainbow-Check Scarf?
description: A style introduced by Acne Studios has spawned one of the biggest winter gear fads in recent memory.
content: The rainbow-check pattern is hard to miss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Dolly Parton’s Pet Gala’ and ‘Crime Nation’
description: The country singer hosts a special that involves a dog runway. The CW airs a new anthology series about true crime.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Feb. 19 - 25. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Currid-Halkett
title: The Future of Medicine Is Unfolding Before Us. Are We Nurturing It?
description: Gene therapies could transform how we treat rare diseases. But will everyone have access?
content: On Jan. 8, 2020, as I was parking my car, I got a long-awaited phone call from one of my son’s doctors. She informed me that our 7-month-old son, Eliot, had Duchenne muscular dystrophy, a fatal neuromuscular disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Two Suspects Charged After Remains of Children Were Found in Concrete and a Suitcase
description: The police in Pueblo, Colo., said that they had arrested Corena Rose Minjarez, 36, and Jesus Dominguez, 35, and charged them with murder.
content: Two people were arrested and charged with the murders of two children whose remains were discovered encased in concrete and inside a suitcase in Colorado, the authorities announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Do I Dress for My Menopause Belly and Mood?
description: Our fashion critic extols the wisdom of layering when trying to account for fluctuations in body temperature and shape, and urges a healthy disregard for the numbers on a tag.
content: Everyone experiences menopause differently. It’s custom-made by nature for each body, tailored to the individual. Yet no matter what symptoms you encounter, the fact that menopause changes your feelings about your psychological and physical self is universal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: What’s a Little Hyperbole Among Friends?
description: The art of the deal has a downside.
content: Gail Collins: So Bret, Donald Trump gets a roughly $355 million fine for fibbing about his fortune. Too much? Too little? Am I wrong for starting to chortle?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Ellen Yan
title: Democrats Hope the Road to House Control Starts in Long Island
description: Tom Suozzi’s victory last week in a special House election stopped a Republican winning streak on Long Island and suggests its House races may be competitive.
content: Within hours of Tom Suozzi’s decisive victory in a House special election in New York last week, the optimistic pronouncements from Democrats began rolling in.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Gravity of Putin Threats Is Dawning on Europe
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 18, 2024.
content: “This is 30 years of underinvestment coming home.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Those $399 Gold Trump Sneakers Are About a Lot More Than Shoes
description: What is Trump really selling when he is selling footwear?
content: Of all the merch hawked by the former president and current presidential candidate Donald J. Trump and related entities over the past few months — the gold (chocolate) bars, the wines, the superhero NFTs — is any of it more Trumpian than the $399 Never Surrender sneakers unveiled over the weekend at Sneaker Con in Philadelphia? They are like a road map to Mr. Trump’s value system and electoral strategy in sartorial form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: New Wisconsin Legislative Maps Diminish G.O.P. Advantage
description: The new maps, which were drawn by the state’s Democratic governor, Tony Evers, and signed into law Monday, include an almost even split between Democratic- and Republican-leaning districts.
content: Gov. Tony Evers of Wisconsin signed into law on Monday new legislative maps that could drastically alter the state’s balance of power, giving Democrats a chance to win control of the state’s legislature for the first time in more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Long Island and the Limits of Sabotage
description: Republicans’ deliberate chaos might not pay off.
content: Last week, Tom Suozzi won handily in the special election in New York’s Third Congressional District to fill the seat vacated by the serial fraudster George Santos — reclaiming the seat that Suozzi previously held. This was the latest in a series of Democratic victories in special elections, victories that seem on their face to run counter to polls showing Donald Trump leading Joe Biden in the presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Katie Thomas, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Diana Nguyen, Will Reid, Alex Stern, Michael Simon Johnson, Michael Benoist, Brendan Klinkenberg, Diane Wong, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Booming Business of Cutting Babies’ Tongues
description: One family’s story of “tongue-tie release” surgery on their newborn.
content: A Times investigation has found that dentists and lactation consultants around the country are pushing “tongue-tie releases” on new mothers struggling to breastfeed, generating huge profits while often harming patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olena Stiazhkina
title: We Ukrainians Are Fighting to Be Free
description: After so many memorials, we want a true anniversary.
content: It usually happens in the middle of the night or at dawn. Russians seem to like to kill the defenseless and helpless. They can’t do it at the front — there they have been repelled — so in the middle of the night, they launch missiles at maternity hospitals, high-rise buildings, train stations, metro stations, schools, libraries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Kirchick
title: The Extradition of Julian Assange Threatens Press Freedoms
description: The First Amendment wasn’t written to protect only those whose ideas and means of expressing them we find agreeable.
content: Fourteen years ago, at a human rights conference in Oslo, I met Julian Assange. From the moment I encountered the wraithlike WikiLeaks founder, I sensed that he might be a morally dubious character. My suspicions were confirmed upon witnessing his speech at the conference, in which he listed Israel alongside Iran and China as part of a “rogue’s gallery of states” and compared the Guantánamo Bay detention facility to a Nazi concentration camp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Vivian Nereim
title: Houthis Say They Shot Down a U.S. Drone Off Yemen
description: The downing of the Reaper drone is another escalation of violence between the United States and Iran-backed groups.
content: The Pentagon is investigating the cause of a crash of an American military surveillance drone off the coast of Yemen on Monday morning, two U.S. officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Ye Has a No. 1 Album for the 11th Time With ‘Vultures 1’
description: The rapper’s collaboration LP with Ty Dolla Sign debuted atop the Billboard 200 with the equivalent of 148,000 in sales.
content: A year and a half ago, the career of Ye — the rapper, producer and controversy generator formerly known as Kanye West — seemed all but dead. After a series of antisemitic remarks in late 2022, Ye lost his major-label record deal and booking agent, along with lucrative fashion partnerships with Adidas, Balenciaga and other brands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: Navalny’s Widow Speaks Out
description: Also, Israel may restrict access to the Aqsa mosque during Ramadan.
content: In a video released yesterday, Yulia Navalnaya said she would carry on her husband’s work to challenge President Vladimir Putin’s autocratic rule and called on his followers to rally alongside her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Emma Goldberg
title: Capital One to Acquire Discover, Creating a Consumer Lending Colossus
description: The all-stock deal, which is valued at $35.3 billion, will combine two of the largest credit card companies in the United States.
content: Capital One announced on Monday that it would acquire Discover Financial Services in an all-stock transaction valued at $35.3 billion, a deal that would merge two of the largest credit card companies in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Don Clark
title: U.S. Awards $1.5 Billion to Chipmaker GlobalFoundries
description: The grant will go toward chips for the auto and defense industries, and is the largest award to date from $39 billion in government funding.
content: The Biden administration on Monday announced a $1.5 billion award to the New York-based chipmaker GlobalFoundries, one of the first sizable grants from a government program aimed at revitalizing semiconductor manufacturing in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Trump Breaks Silence on Navalny Death, but Doesn’t Condemn Putin
description: His winding social media post on Monday contained no reference to Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president, who has been widely condemned after the death of one of his most vocal critics, Aleksei A. Navalny.
content: Days after the death of the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny was first reported, Donald J. Trump broke his silence in a social media post on Monday that barely mentioned Mr. Navalny and that did not condemn President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. Instead, he used Mr. Navalny’s death to suggest that his own legal battles amounted to political persecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David C. Adams and Andre Paultre
title: The Wife of Haiti’s Assassinated President Is Accused in His Killing
description: Martine Moïse, the widow of President Jovenel Moïse, was charged by a Haitian judge with conspiring in his assassination. She was seriously injured in the attack.
content: A Haitian judge has indicted 51 people for their roles in the 2021 assassination of President Jovenel Moïse, including his wife, Martine Moïse, who is accused of being an accomplice, despite being seriously wounded in the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump and Haley Will Face Off in South Carolina. Here’s What to Know.
description: The state’s Republican primary is scheduled for Saturday, Feb. 24.
content: The foursome of early Republican nominating contests will soon come to a close with the South Carolina primary, following the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary last month and the Nevada primary and caucuses this month.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Trump Effect’: Lost Friends and a Jaundiced View of Humanity
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about how politics has ruptured friendships. Also: Common ground; mean girls; problem solvers; backyard skating rinks.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: The Met Aims to Get Harlem Right, the Second Time Around
description: The museum catches up to the vital lessons of the Harlem Renaissance, with its American, European and African exchanges and its cultural solidarity.
content: Notoriously, in the winter of 1969 the Metropolitan Museum of Art opened its first exhibition devoted to African American culture, but with a show devoid of art. Called “Harlem on My Mind: Cultural Capital of Black America, 1900—1968,” it was a photomural-with-texts affair of a kind found in ethnology museums.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: It’s Alive! EC Comics Returns
description: Oni Press will revive the beloved horror and sci-fi name with new stories starting this summer.
content: EC Comics, which specialized in tales of horror, crime and suspense, and was shut down in the “moral panic” of the 1950s, is making a comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Blair
title: How I Designed My Perfect Connections Solve
description: An editor finds fun by making the game just a bit harder for himself.
content: Perfection is in my job description. I lead The New York Times’s Flexible Editing team, a group that’s relentlessly committed to perfecting the language, grammar and quality of writing across our news report. It’s a hard switch to turn off, especially after work when I’m trying to pursue diversions that most people find relaxing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: TikTok Is Subject of E.U. Inquiry Over ‘Addictive Design’
description: The European Commission said it would investigate whether the site violated online laws aimed at protecting children from harmful content.
content: European Union regulators on Monday opened an investigation into TikTok over potential breaches of online content rules aimed at protecting children, saying the popular social media platform’s “addictive design” risked exposing young people to harmful content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: An Olympic Equestrian Rode a Horse in a ‘Mankini.’ Australia Loves Him.
description: Shane Rose was briefly barred from competition after he wore a G-string bikini costume. The stunt won wide public support.
content: When the Australian equestrian and three-time Olympic medalist Shane Rose mounted his horse for a costumed competition wearing only a G-string bikini, or “mankini,” he thought it was all in good — albeit somewhat uncomfortable — fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Monday Briefing
description: The impact of Aleksei Navalny’s death.
content: Aleksei Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, died on Friday in a penal colony. He was 47.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Chris Cameron
title: Nikki Haley Again Calls for a TikTok Ban Over Privacy Concerns
description: During a Fox News town hall event, Ms. Haley criticized President Biden and Donald Trump for their actions related to the platform.
content: The Republican Party might have challenges with outreach to Generation Z, but Nikki Haley, appearing in a Fox News town hall event on Sunday, said the answer was not TikTok, the Chinese-owned social media platform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Juliette Binoche: Everyone Should Make Films With Their Ex-Boyfriends
description: The star of “The Taste of Things” explains why working with her former romantic partner Benoît Magimel was freeing, and weighs in on an Oscar controversy.
content: Some actors come to embody a national cinema through an alchemical combination of demeanor and film choices. You might say that Clint Eastwood is the quintessential American icon, for example, or that Hugh Grant is the embodiment of a certain kind of Britishness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: For Michigan’s Economy, Electric Vehicles Are Promising and Scary
description: In a presidential battleground state, electric vehicles have emerged as a contested piece of the economic future — a job-killer or a job-creator.
content: Last fall, Tiffanie Simmons, a second-generation autoworker, endured a six-week strike at the Ford Motor factory just west of Detroit where she builds Bronco S.U.V.s. That yielded a pay raise of 25 percent over the next four years, easing the pain of reductions that she and other union workers swallowed more than a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liza Weisstuch
title: Glamour, Travel, Sexism: When Flight Attendants Fought Back
description: Decades ago, “stewardesses” earned less than men, couldn’t get married or gain weight, and had to retire at 32. A key figure in a landmark lawsuit looks back at a not-so-golden era.
content: In 1958, when Mary Pat Laffey Inman became a stewardess — as they were then called — for Northwest Airlines, she was 20 years old and the clock was already ticking. At 32, she would be forced to retire. That is, if she didn’t marry, get pregnant or even gain too much weight before that: All were grounds for termination. It was the golden age of aviation for everyone except, perhaps, the women serving in-flight meals to the nattily dressed passengers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: Israel’s Occupation of Palestinian Territories Draws Focus of U.N. Court
description: Dozens of countries are expected to argue before the International Court of Justice about the legality of Israeli actions in the West Bank and East Jerusalem.
content: The International Court of Justice began hearing arguments on Monday on the legality of Israel’s occupation of Palestinian territories. It is the first time the world’s highest court has been asked to give an advisory opinion on the issue, which has been the subject of years of debates and resolutions at the United Nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Anti-Trump Burnout: The Resistance Says It’s Exhausted
description: Bracing for yet another election against Donald Trump, America’s liberals are feeling the fatigue. “We’re kind of, like, crises-ed out,” one Democrat said.
content: In 2017 they donned pink hats to march on Washington, registering their fury with Donald J. Trump by the hundreds of thousands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4.2 Million Homes in California
description: A Mediterranean-style house in Beverly Hills, a desert retreat in Pioneertown and a Spanish-style home in San Francisco.
content: This house is just off Coldwater Canyon, less than a 10-minute drive from Franklin Canyon Reservoir and the walking trails winding around it. It is three miles from Sunset Boulevard, putting it within 10 minutes of the Sunset Strip and the center of Beverly Hills, and within 15 minutes of the Los Angeles Country Club, where the U.S. Open Golf Championship was held last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘True Detective’ Season 4, Episode 6 Recap: Stories Are Stories
description: The season ended with a finale that provided plenty of answers while clinging to a bit of mystery.
content: One of the tricky parts of a ghost story like “True Detective: Night Country” is the banal, inevitable business of having to explain events that were once teasingly inexplicable. It is more haunting, for example, to imagine a supernatural force turning terrified scientists into an Arctic “corpsicle” than to learn that they were commandeered by a vigilante band of Indigenous women taking justice into their own hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris, Gabriel Blanco and Karen Hanley
title: Our Critic Breaks Down His Picks
description: With the Oscars around the corner, Wesley Morris, a critic at The New York Times Magazine, has created a list of distinguished acting performances from the past year.
content: With the Oscars around the corner, Wesley Morris, a critic at The New York Times Magazine, has created a list of distinguished acting performances from the past year.
source.name: The New York Times
